newsitem.title: FRANCE: Saint-Gobain sees big gain in 1997 profit.
newsitem.headline: Saint-Gobain sees big gain in 1997 profit.

text.p: French glassmaker Saint-Gobain, which is a key player in a planned merger between utilities company Lyonnaise des Eaux and holding group Cie de Suez, expects to boost net profit by at least 20 percent in 1997, its chairman Jean-Louis Beffa said on Tuesday.
He was speaking at a briefing on the company's 1996 results published in January which showed a 2.6 percent gain in net attributable income to 4.32 billion francs ($767.9 million).
"The total increase in Saint-Gobain's net result will be at least 20 percent," Beffa said.
Beffa also called on Suez, in which Saint-Gobain holds 6.3 percent, to pay out some 10 percent of its 34 billion francs in financial assets ahead of merging with Lyonnaise des Eaux.
"I have to say that out of the 34 billion francs in financial assets, a distribution of around 10 percent to shareholders would not seem shocking to me," he added.
Suez investors had been let down by the company's disastrous property lending and was now facing new risks as it refocuses as a utilities company by merging with Lyonnaise des Eaux, he said.
He added that "all calculations show that Suez is worth around 340 to 350 francs" per share. Suez was trading around 287.50 francs around midday on Tuesday.

Beffa added that Saint-Gobain would reduce its holdings in its group of stable shareholders, which include Suez, utilities firm Cie Generale des Eaux, bank Banque Nationale de Paris (BNP) and insurer Axa-UAP.
Asked by reporters whether that disposal plan included the Suez stake, he said "Yes". Asked how much of Suez he would sell, Beffa said, "a reasonbable proportion."
Newspaper Le Monde reported Saint-Gobain would halve its stake but a Saint-Gobain spokeswoman declined to confirm the figure.

Saint-Gobain is unwinding its cross-shareholdings with other French firms, as part of a strategy of viewing them purely as financial investments, Beffa said. Only the stake in lens-maker Essilor was not under review, as Saint-Gobain regards it as an industrial investment, he said.
"We must have a vision of profitability" on share cross-holdings, Beffa told analysts. The group would reduce its stakes this year, he added.

Saint-Gobain joins the list of big French companies, including Elf-Aquitaine and Alcatel Alsthom, keen to realise profits on shares held as part of a pact of cross-shareholdings, which have served as a defence against hostile take-overs.
The rise in share prices on the Paris Bourse over the last year offers scope for capital gains.
Shares in Saint-Gobain were down 3.5 percent at 822 franc at 1145 GMT, while the CAC-40 Paris blue-chip index was down 3.04 percent.
